history.content:
Think about your budget and hours. If you are making a lot of money and working long hours, being closer is a major life benefiter. If you have a more moderate schedule and budget is tighter, probably stay in Berkeley.

I had an internship during the summer that had crazy hours and my only saving grace was it was online (because of COVID) so I had a few hours a day to do things like cook, take care of myself etc. If I had to give up 2.5 hours to commuting, it would have been hard (you'll need time to decompress and food/laundry might cost more if not cooking or washing it yourself).

In contrast, I had an in person job that was only around 40 - 50 hours a week a few years earlier and I was totally fine being an hour away.

children.subject: @Anonymous Beaker [OP] you're probably eligible for the Clipper Start card which is 50% off on Caltrain and 20% off Bart

I think you could also consider public transportation such as Bart/Caltrain as well if you don't like to drive. Personally, it may be a bit troublesome since there isn't a direct train but if you take the Bart to Milbrae from Downtown Berkeley and then switch at Milbrae for a Caltrain to Palo Alto, you can reach the Caltrain station at Palo Alto. It takes about an hour and a half each way but it may be more comfortable than driving.

I'm in a very similar situation, except I have to commute to Sunnyvale instead of Palo Alto and I went through a very similar dilemma. Decided against moving closer because of obscene rent prices and crossed out taking public transit because it'd take 2.5-3 hours. 

In the end, I ended up settling on driving, but I'm going to leave at 6 am everyday. The reason is that I can go workout, shower, have breakfast and then go to work. My company gives me gym benefits and free meals, so it'll end up working out well! You should check if your company gives you access to at least a gym or subsidizes a gym membership!
There are a lot of commuter groups on facebook, that could work out pretty nicely for you. If you're going at ~6am, allegedly you can make it there in well under an hour.

Thank you guys for all the answers! Some things to note are

- the company I will be interning for is notorious for overtime and in particular since my team is new I will definitely need to do lots of overtime.

- gym does exist, but I heard practically no one uses it. Also, sleep is more important for me.

- gas price doesn't look like it's going to go down.

- there are many other interns and I probably can find a lease for ~ $1300. However, I will still be paying $600 for the housing in Berkeley each month.

With overtime, I do think moving closer is a better option. Also, since gas is almost twice as the usual price I am rethinking of the cost of driving.

I was pretty much set on staying in Berkeley, but with y'all's perspectives and some others', I am back into this dilemma hahaha.

history.content:
I thankfully got an internship for the summer which I am very happy about. The only issue is the commute. The internship is in Palo Alto, and since I didn't know I would get this job I already signed a lease in Berkeley for the summer (I cannot sublease the house). The job offers a stipend, but it's just enough for a month or a bit more considering the cost of living in Palo Alto.

Here are my two options:

1. Move to Palo Alto. Housing for a single is about $2,500 but I am sure I am missing on some better options. However, I am thinking it will cost me overall a minimum of $2,500 considering everything else like moving, furniture, etc. And I have to pay the rent at Berkeley which will be $600 since my roommates agreed to subsidize my rent if I choose to not live in Berkeley for the summer. The commute, however, will be less than 20 minutes via bike. 

2. Stay in Berkeley. I have a car (~ 30 mpg), but the commute is about 1 hour and a half on average. If I leave at 6am, it's 1~1.5 hrs. But anything after that can take me up to 2 hours, with 1.5 hrs being average. The rent here is cheap ($1200) and my roommates and I are very close. We also have a great system - shared groceries, food, etc. So I don't have to do many chores except occasional cleaning. Foodwise, we usually just make a bunch of food and it's for everyone. I almost never have to cook even right now. But the gas and commute hours are murderous.

So it comes down to spending an extra couple thousand dollars vs. driving an average of 2.5 hours each day for work. The latter is definitely cheaper and fun. But it looks extremely painful. Maybe I should just suck it up and drive - and I like driving. I am very much leaning towards option 2 fyi.

If anyone has better options than what I listed, please let me know. If anyone ever had to contemplate the same thing, what did you do?

Any advice will be nice.
history.subject: Summer Internship Housing - Palo Alto
